131378526.review:
No quiero desmerecer el esfuerzo y los conocimientos de los creadores. Pero cuanto se puede hacer con tan poco.

Otaku's Adventure es una novela grafica simple basada en dibujos con un poco de movimiento y mini juegos que cuentan la historia del tipico friki intentando levantarse una minita. Nos cuentan varias historias donde podremos tomar distintas decisiones y todas nos mandan a un final diferente. De tanto en tanto nos mandan algun mini juego que la verdad son faciles pero muy divertidos. Con alrededor de 30 finales distintos y solo 3 buenos, te incentiva ir desbloqueandolos todos hasta completarlos como en un album de figuritas. 

La verdad que lo recomiendo mucho y encima vale dos mangos.

80417488.review:
Kind of Pro: Some of the puzzles are interesting for a point&click game
Cons: Lazy writing, sexist cliche story, bad translation to english, boring characters, repetitive character design (stolen from other games and animes).

I believe the main part of a point and click game, besides the puzzles, is the story. If the story doesn't make you have a slightly empathy towards the main character - or to connect to the world - the game is going to suck. And this is the case of Otaku Story.

I'm not saying you can't tell stories about Otakus or whatever other men's culture - you can. But we're expecting a more deeper and interesting portrait of that and not just a collection of expected behaviours that you can see everyday in forums throughout the internet. I think wattpad fanfics are more entertaining than this.

I don't recommend this game to anyone that likes point&click games or Otaku culture.

Short point-and-click, with a central minigame in each route. Everything is controlled by the mouse.
My playtime of 12 hours is with getting all the achievements.
There are 3 routes, one for each girl. The routes are vastly different from each other and feel like long journeys despite being pretty short.

The english translation is kinda bad but some think it adds to the experience. I don't, but at the same time I don't think it's bad enough to warrant skipping the game.

There are 3 good endings (one for each girl) and multiple bad endings. The bad endings range from obvious to surprisingly hidden. Most of them are pretty funny, and with a sole exception they're over pretty quickly and you can get right back to where you were.

Closing statement: Gohard is best girl.

I thoroughly enjoyed myself playing this game. I loved the multiple girls you could try to date, and I especially loved the multiple endings this game has to offer. It does have a lot of references to Kio's Adventure, so I found them funny and made the game a bit more enjoyable in my opinion. The art style was kinda simple but cute and I liked the comic book aspect. Some of the minigames was a pain in the butt for me (like trying to do the shooting or alien fighting ones without losing any health was hard). Just like Kio's Adventure, this game does have a lot of typos, but it does add to the humor of the game. My biggest issue with the game is the lack of a skip button (even a skip for only seen text would have been nice). A lot of my time was spent trying to quickly go through text I've seen just to find all the endings. A skip feature for text would have been very, very appreciated (and not just a skip feature for already seen endings...).

Overall, I do recommend this game if you enjoy VNs/dating sims or finding multiple endings in games. It's not necessary to play Kio's Adventure first, but I do recommend playing it before doing this game just to fully understand all the Kio references.

60743788.review:
I did not think I would like a game like Otaku’s Adventure (cringe humor is really hard for me to like), but honestly, this is one of the best visual novels I have ever played if not the best. In my original review, I was a bit more critical, but after playing more visual novels and dating sims then coming back and seeing what the DLC has to offer I found myself really liking it and being nostalgic for my last playthrough. 

So as far as gameplay goes it does offer your standard fare visual novel choice system, but this is often quite limited. The choices you are given usually are between just two and they are few and far between, so in that way, this game is weaker than some other offerings. However, what makes up for this lack of choice is its mini-games. Unlike other visual novels, this game has a plethora of mini-games to break up the monotony and make the game actually feel like… Well, a game! The DLC did a really good job of offering a whole lot of mini-games with its storyline. Beyond the mini-games, there are also moments where the game is more akin to a point-and-click adventure. Still, I think the most impressive part is that there is a small RPG with turn-based combat and everything just built into it. This melding of gameplay elements makes each story path that much more exciting to explore and sets it above many other visual novels in my eyes.

The core of the game though is the story and writing and I must say that I think it really makes the game shine. First off, this game is funny. I chuckled out loud many times which for me means that this game was downright hilarious. I thought the cringe would be too much, but it is not too bad all things considered. I did not like the bathroom/crude humor (I have never been a fan of anything like that), but it is not excessive, so it receives a pass. As for all the different storylines, I found all of them to be compellingly written and filled with endings (both good and bad) that are worth seeing. It used to be that one of the endings was far weaker than the other two, but the DLC fixed that, though it doubles down on making that story far longer than the others which makes the other two a bit more neglected. Nonetheless, I appreciated the story and all that it had to offer. One criticism though is that because this game was not originally written in English it does have some spelling errors. It does look like that after the DLC was released they were less frequent (I only found one in my replay, it was far worse before it). I highly recommend getting to all good endings, I enjoyed them (the fantasy one is especially worth seeing). What great writing!

The sound design in this game is also pretty good. Yeah, some of the sound design feels like it is from a stock sounds collection (probably because they are), but it all works well together so I find that acceptable. What I did find that I loved though is the music, a lot of it is simple, but it plays well to the mood and setting the game is trying to enhance. The best one by far though is from the DLC and it convinced me to buy the soundtrack because I liked it enough. The song is The Otherworld Winter, and the emotion it gave me was something special, hopefully, others feel the same way. Overall, Otaku’s Adventure has good sound design in my opinion.

Graphically I immensely enjoyed this game’s style. I swear every anime visual novel has essentially the same visual style nowadays and it is so boring. This more simplistic style fits the vibe and makes the game stand out. I could see a lot of people feeling like it seems too much like a flash game, but that doesn’t matter, all that matters is that it looks good. There are plenty of times when the scenes are artistically impressive, art styles are changed slightly to change tones and add emotions, and the emotions of the characters are properly portrayed visually. All-in-all I am a fan of the look.

Otaku’s Adventure is worth purchasing even at full price. As a completionist, spending $9 for a game and its DLC (which you should definitely get along with the base game) that I spent just shy of 11 hours of gameplay is a good deal. Seeing as how this game has a wonderful story, a strong variety of gameplay, great music, and a style that I appreciate. So, I think I can say that I recommend paying full price for it instead of waiting for a sale. The care and creativity that this game received deserves to be rewarded. Otaku’s Adventure may not be for everyone, but as far as I have played I think this is my favorite visual novel and dating sim, despite how cringe that may be. XD

This game is a solid (´・ω・`) out of (´・ω・`), give it a try I don’t think you will be disappointed.

54579894.review:
If you're even considering this game, buy it.

One of the greatest point-and-click adventures ever! Soooo many branching storylines that adjust to your decisions, and just absurdly chaotic and hilarious. Obviously, as the title would suggest, lots of anime/otaku references.

The translation is kinda sloppy (from Chinese), but for some reason... it adds to the charm of the game in a strange way.

It's a point-and-click adventure with tons and tons of mini-games and you never really have to be afraid of failure at any point. You can't softlock, there's an ending for any set of decisions or path you may go down, whether it's immediate, or leading you down a completely different story branch.

I really wasn't expecting much, and didn't expect to just have a grin on my face the entire time I played it.

54401376.review:
Very enjoyable game. I liked all the different endings and dialogue, particularly for its humor. While the main character is a bit cliche, the varying story lines are great and some of the events in them heartwarming. The parodying of some other games and common tropes was also well made. For the most part, it's a simple game to play, so there's not really a barrier for anyone to try it out.

My main critique is the RPG system in the third story line. While entertaining in its own right, I feel that the game becomes too slow-paced and different nature compared to the rest, considering the need to grind for upgrades to defeat some of the bosses. Another (potential) downside is the English translations being occasionally poor. I personally enjoyed them for comical effect, but they are a bit of an annoyance for some players; your mileage may vary.

I felt hooked enough to go for all endings and achievements, but even if you have no interest in full completion, I would say it's worth its price.

I am very glad I stumbled upon this hidden gem, I have never experienced something like this before, it's very innovative!

At first glance you'd think this is just your average visual novel but no...it actually blends the genre with point and click adventure, arcade target shooting, arcade fighting and rpg. On top of it, it's extremely well executed.

It's mainly visual novel and point and click but each girl has their own unique genre associated with them in their story in the form of mini games (there are 3).

I found all of them hilarious! They are pretty surreal, my favorite one was Gohard's. (lots of meme references too!)

Another unique aspect of this game that it has so many endings, there are good ones, bad ones, random ones, downright surprising ones, hilarious ones. There's also a good amount of puzzles to solve, fitting art and the funky English translation just makes it all the more charming.

For the price it's basically a steal, it has a good 7-10 hours of content depending on your speed (and if you want all achievements). I took 14 hours.

I definitely recommend it. Can't wait for a sequel, if it ever gets one.

50804449.review:
Pretty solid game for the price. The translation I found, while poor quality, conversely adds charm to the style while still being able to make sense of what it means.
While I liked all the routes, the pacing and nonsense for the 'third' route is quite a bit different from the others so I could see that specific route putting some people off.

Good humor with chaotic plot. Not the game if you want serious plot or emotional romance, but few people probably expect either of those going in.

Down side would be lack of being able to fastforward through text, not being able to save at literally any moment outside of fights (just most moments), as well as saves not actually being where you save but at the start of the scene in story moments combined with the no fast forward can make retrying parts somewhat tedious.
I also didn't like only having 6 save slots (I like to save a lot at different spots for many reasons) but it's probably not important for most people.

Overall pretty good. Much better than expected, at least.

50785755.review:
This is a real hidden gem!
It's super entertaining with funny stories and characters, beautiful art-style, greatly thought-out point&click adventure puzzles, a broad array of awesomely made minigames (like boxing where you have to outsmart the moves of your opponents to win, a funny shooting game and a suprisingly fleshed-out classic (J)RPG amidst one of the storys). The different story branches are chosen by the choices you make and hidden secrets you find. You will get entirely different ways and outcomes depending of what you do with many hidden endings and alternative routes to go. It's all of really high quality!

The english translation is mostly good, sometimes bad, sometimes charmingly funny, but always understandable.

I'd say give this a go if it looks even slightly interesting to you. It's brilliant! :D
